text: Infections of the cardiovascular system include septicemia, endocarditis (inflammation of the heart’s inner lining), pericarditis (inflammation of the heart’s outer lining), myocarditis (inflammation of heart muscle), and, possibly, atherosclerosis (deposition of fatty substances along the inner lining of arteries; eTopic 26.6).
The cardiovascular system, which is composed of the heart, arteries, veins, and capillaries, delivers oxygen, nutrients, and immune system components to all tissues of the body.
In practice, however, the terms “septicemia” and “bacteremia” are often used interchangeably.
Nevertheless, Gram-positives, Gram-negatives, aerobes, and anaerobes can all produce septicemia under the right conditions.
Septicemia is, by strict definition, the presence of bacteria or viruses in the blood.
The presence of viruses is a condition more specifically called viremia, while bacteria in the circulation is more specifically called bacteremia.
Pathogens disseminated in this way can cause infections in many different organ systems.
There are pathogens that can directly infect the heart or the endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
Septicemia can develop from a local tissue infection situated anywhere in the body, although blood factors such as complement can nonspecifically kill many types of bacteria that enter the blood.

It can be a consequence of many bacterial diseases, such as brucellosis, gonorrhea, psittacosis, staphylococcal and Among the many viral causes are coxsackievirus, echovirus, heart are always serious.
We will examine both types of infections in this section.
However, the blood itself can also become infected or serve as a mass transit system to spread pathogens throughout the body.
Endocarditis can be either viral or bacterial in origin.
Viral infections, although common, are rarely life-threatening in healthy individuals and are usually asymptomatic.
